Package agave.conversion

A collection of default Converters that Agave uses to convert from String parameters to higher level objects.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Converter<InputT,OutputT> Converts an object from the input type to the output type.
PartConverter<OutputT> Converts an object from a string array to a collection of the output type.
StringConverter<OutputT> Converts an object from the input type to the output type.
 

Class Summary
BooleanConverter Converts an input String into a Boolean object.
BufferedImageConverter Converts an uploaded file directly into a manipulatable BufferedImage.
ByteConverter Converts an input String into a signed decimal Byte object.
CharacterConverter Converts a String input into a Character object.
DateConverter Converts a supplied date string into a java.util.Date by leveraging DateFormat.format()'s short locale-specific implementation.
DateTimeConverter Converts a supplied date string into a java.util.Date and time by leveraging DateFormat.format()'s short locale-specific implementation.
DoubleConverter Converts a String input into a Double object.
FloatConverter Converts a String input into a Float object.
IntegerConverter Converts a String input into a Integer object.
LongConverter Converts a String input into a Long object.
ShortConverter Converts a String input into a Short object.
 

Package agave.conversion Description

A collection of default Converters that Agave uses to convert from String parameters to higher level objects. The String parameters can come from form inputs, request parameters, or URI pattern positional parameters, in that order where the latter provides greater specificity.

An example of each is:

Form Inputs
Form inputs come from a submitted HTML form, where the parameter name is the name supplied with some input, eg: 
  <form method="post" action="${contextPath}/some/uri">
    <input type="text" name="parameterNameToBeConverted" />
  </form>
Request Parameters
Request parameters come from the HTTP request query string, eg: 
  http://localhost:8080/contextPath/some/resource?parameterNameToBeConverted=parameterValue
URI Pattern Positional Parameters
URI pattern positional parameters are variables whose value are supplied with the request URL and are embedded withing the actual URL and not the query string. These positional params are specified by variable delimiters in the HandlesRequestsTo annotation. For example, the following annotation has a positional parameter: 
  @HandlesRequestsTo("/profile/${username}")
  public Destination displayProfile(HandlerContext) {
      ...
  }
